abstract.title: EPUB Content Documents 3.1
abstract.para: EPUB Content Documents 3.1 specifies a usage of HTML, SVG and CSS optimized for representation of structured, composable, and accessible documents.

section.title: Purpose and Scope
section.para: This specification, EPUB Content Documents 3.1, defines profiles of HTML5, SVG, and CSS for use in the context of EPUBÂ® Publications.
This specification supersedes EPUB Content Documents 3.0.1 . Refer to for more information on the differences between this specification and its predecessor.

section.title: Relationship to HTML5
section.para: The HTML document type defined by this specification is based on W3C , and inherits all definitions of semantics, structure and processing behaviors from the HTML5 specification unless otherwise specified.
In addition, this specification defines a set of extensions to the W3C HTML5 document model. Extensions that are only available in XML serialized HTML Content Documents are being phased out.

This specification defines a simplified processing model that does not require EPUB Reading Systems to support scripting, HTML5 forms or the HTML5 DOM. Reading Systems conformant with this specification are only required to be able to process a conforming . As support for scripting and HTML5 forms are optional Reading System features, a conformant Reading System might not be a fully-conformant HTML5 User Agent (i.e., it might not implement the complete HTML5 processing model).

section.title: Relationship to SVG
section.para: This specification defines a restricted subset of SVG 1.1 to represent vector graphics inline in HTML Content Documents and as standalone SVG Content Documents.

section.title: Relationship to CSS
section.para: The CSS profile defined in this specification has CSS 2.1 as its baseline. Any CSS Style Sheet that conforms to CSS 2.1 may be used in the context of an EPUB Publication, except as noted in .
This specification also incorporates features defined by CSS3 Modules and introduces EPUB-specific CSS constructs.

section.title: Future Maintenance
section.para: This specification references W3C specifications that are not yet final, and incompatible changes to them may occur in the future that would cause EPUB 3.1 Content Documents that were previously conformant to no longer be conformant to the latest versions of the referenced specifications.
The IDPF anticipates revisions to this specification, as necessary, to update the normative constraints defined herein if and when such incompatible changes occur.

section.title: Namespace prefix mapping
section.para: For convenience, the following namespace prefixes are used in this specification without explicitly being declared. To use any of these prefixes in an , a declaration is required.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: This section defines a profile of for creating HTML Content Documents. An instance of an HTML document that conforms to this profile is a and is referred to in this specification as an .
Unless otherwise specified, this specification inherits all definitions of semantics, structure and processing behaviors from the specification.

section.xreflabel: HTML Content Documents â Content Conformance
section.title: Content Conformance
section.para: An must meet all of the following criteria:

listitem.para: It must be an document that conforms to the HTML or XHTML syntax.
If it uses the HTML syntax , it must be encoded in UTF-8 or UTF-16 .
If it uses the XHTML syntax , it must meet the conformance constraints for XML documents defined in .
For all document constructs used that are defined by , it must conform to the conformance criteria defined for those constructs in that specification, unless explicitly overridden in .
It may include extensions to the grammar as defined in , and must conform to all content conformance constraints defined therein.

HTML Content Documents that use the HTML syntax
should use the file extension .html.

HTML Content Document that use the XHTML syntax
should use the file extension .xhtml

section.xreflabel: HTML Content Documents â Reading System Conformance
section.title: Reading System Conformance
section.para: A conformant must meet all of the following criteria for processing HTML Content Documents:

listitem.para: Unless explicitly defined by this specification as overridden, it must process HTML Content Documents using semantics defined by the specification and honor any applicable User Agent conformance constraints expressed therein.
It must support Content Documents that use either the HTML or XHTML syntaxes defined in .
It must meet all Reading System conformance criteria defined in .
It must recognize and adapt behaviorally to the constraints defined in .
It must meet the Reading System conformance criteria defined in .
It must support visual rendering of HTML Content Documents as defined in .
It should recognize embedded ARIA markup and support exposure of any given ARIA roles, states and properties to platform accessibility APIs .

section.title: Introduction
section.para: This section defines EPUB 3.1 extensions to the underlying document model.

The extensions are divided into two categories: those that can be used in HTML Content Documents regardless of whether they use the HTML or XHTML syntax (), and those designed when EPUB 3 only supported the XHTML syntax and for which no equivalent functionality is available in the HTML syntax ().

The W3C is actively developing many specifications that enhance and extend the core functionality defined in , but if these extensions are not listed in this section they are not available for use in EPUB Content Documents. New additions are considered in each revision to the standard.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: Semantic inflection is the process of attaching additional meaning about the specific purpose and/or nature an element plays in an . The implementation of the ARIA role attribute is used to express domain-specific semantics in HTML Content Documents, with the inflection(s) it carries complementing the underlying host vocabulary.

The applied semantics are intended to refine the meaning of their containing elements; they are not provided to override their nature (e.g., the attribute can be used to indicate a section is a chapter in a work, but is not designed to turn p elements into list items to avoid proper list structures).

Semantic metadata is not intended for direct human consumption; it instead provides a controlled way for Reading Systems and other User Agents to learn more about the structure and content of a document, providing them the opportunity to enhance the reading experience for Users.

This specification defines a method for semantic inflection using the attribute axis: instead of adding new elements, the role attribute can be appended to existing elements to inflect the desired semantics.

section.title: The ARIA role Attribute
section.para: The implementation of the ARIA role attribute is the recommended method for inflecting semantics on EPUB Content Documents.
The role attribute supersedes the epub:type attribute, as it is compatible with both the HTML and XHTML syntaxes of , which ensures a single common method for adding semantics.

The primary vocabulary for roles for use in HTML Content Documents is the W3C Digital Publishing WAI-ARIA Module 1.0 , but roles defined in and in other modules maintained by the WAI-ARIA Working Group are also valid.

annotation.para: Need to find out if the WAI-ARIA group will be maintaining a registry of role modules so we can point to a concrete page here.

note.para: Mapping of properties in the to applicable ARIA roles is available at .

section.para: Due to the tight binding the role attribute has with assistive technologies, Authors are strongly encouraged to familiarize themselves with proper use of the attribute and roles, as outlined in . Incorrect application of roles to elements could negatively impact on the usability of publications.

note.para: See also for more information about the use of the roles in HTML.

section.title: The epub:type Attribute
section.para: The epub:type attribute has been superseded by the ARIA role attribute, but may still be used in EPUB Content Documents.
The epub:type attribute is retained primarily for compatibility for modular extensions for which equivalent roles do not yet exist.
Authors should use the role attribute whenever an equivalent semantic is available, but may include both attributes.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: Unlike semantic inflection, which is about refining the structures within your markup, semantic enrichment enables the layering of meaning into the content in order to facilitate machine processing.
The and specifications both define sets of attributes that can be used in HTML Content Documents to semantically enrich the content.

section.title: Content Conformance
section.para: A conformant must meet all of the following criteria:

listitem.para: It must allow the use of attributes as defined in that specification.
It must allow the use of attributes as defined in .

section.title: Processing Requirements
section.para: Reading Systems may process and attributes as defined in their respective specifications, but such support is optional.

section.title: Alternate Style Tags
section.para: In accordance with , the link element class attribute may include any of the following values: horizontal, vertical, day and night. These values inherit the semantics defined by that specification for their use.
Reading Systems should select and utilize such tagged style sets as appropriate, and as described in that specification.

caution.para: The following features are only available in HTML Content Documents that use the XHTML syntax of .

Deprecated features will be removed from a future version of the specification. Features not marked as deprecated are expected to be harmonized with the HTML syntax, in which case they will not be available in their current form.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: The W3C Speech Synthesis Markup Language is a language used for assisting engines in generating synthetic speech. Although SSML is designed as a standalone document type, it also defines semantics suitable for use within other host languages.
This specification recasts the SSML 1.1 phoneme element as two attributes â ssml:ph and ssml:alphabet â and makes them available within HTML Content Documents.
Reading Systems with capabilities should support the SSML Attributes as defined below.

section.title: The ssml:ph attribute
section.para: The ssml:ph attribute specifies a phonemic/phonetic pronunciation of the text represented by the element to which the attribute is attached.

listitem.para: Global attribute. May be specified on all elements with which a phonetic equivalent can logically be associated (e.g., elements that contain textual information).
Must not be specified on a descendant of an element that already carries this attribute.
A phonemic/phonetic expression, syntactically valid with respect to the phonemic/phonetic alphabet being used.

section.para: This attribute inherits all the semantics of the SSML 1.1 phoneme element ph attribute, with the following addition:

listitem.para: When the ssml:ph attribute appears on an element that has text node descendants, the corresponding document text to which the pronunciation applies is the string that results from concatenating the descendant text nodes, in document order. The specified phonetic pronunciation must therefore logically match the element's textual data in its entirety (i.e., not just an isolated part of its content).

note.para: Reading Systems that support the SSML Attributes and PLS Documents must honor the defined precedence rules for these two constructs.

section.title: The ssml:alphabet attribute
section.para: The ssml:alphabet attribute specifies which phonemic/phonetic pronunciation alphabet is used in the value of the attribute.

listitem.para: Global attribute. May be specified on any element.
The name of the pronunciation alphabet used in the value of (inherited).

section.para: This attribute inherits all the semantics of the SSML 1.1 phoneme element alphabet attribute, with the following addition:

listitem.para: The value of the ssml:alphabet attribute is inherited in the document tree. The pronunciation alphabet used in a given ssml:ph attribute value is determined by locating the first occurrence of the ssml:alphabet attribute starting with the element on which the ssml:ph attribute appears, followed by the nearest ancestor element.

section.para: Reading Systems that support the SSML Attributes feature of this specification should support the IPA alphabet , as expressed by the value "ipa".

section.title: Custom Attributes
section.para: Reading Systems may introduce functionality not defined in this specification to enhance the rendering of EPUB Publications. To facilitate this experimentation, vendors may define custom attributes for use in HTML Content Documents.

Custom attributes may be included on any element in an HTML Content Document provided such attributes are from a foreign namespace, which is defined as a namespace that does not map to either of the following URIs:

Custom attributes, and the behaviors associated with them, must not alter the integrity of an EPUB Publication. The content must remain consumable by a User without any information loss or other significant deterioration, regardless of the Reading System it is rendered on.

note.para: To facilitate interoperability of custom attributes across Reading Systems, vendors are strongly encouraged to document any extensions they implement at http://www.idpf.org/epub/extensions/attributes.

section.title: HTML5 Deviations and Constraints
section.para: This section defines deviations from, and constraints on, the underlying document model applicable to EPUB 3.1 HTML Content Documents.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: HTML Content Documents support embedded but limit its usage to a restricted subset of the full MathML markup language.
This subset is designed to ease the implementation burden on Reading Systems and to promote accessibility, while retaining compatibility with User Agents.

note.para: The mathml property of the item element indicates that an HTML Content Document contains embedded MathML.

section.title: Content Conformance
section.para: Any occurrence of MathML markup in HTML Content Documents must conform to the constraints expressed in the MathML specification , with the following additional restrictions:

listitem.para: The math element must contain only Presentation MathML, with the exception of the annotation-xml element as defined below.
Content MathML may be included within MathML markup in HTML Content Documents, and, when present, must occur within an annotation-xml child element of an semantics element.

When Content MathML is included as per the previous condition, the given annotation-xml element's encoding attribute must be set to either of the functionally-equivalent values MathML-Content or application/mathml-content+xml, and its name attribute must be set to contentequiv.

Elements and attributes marked as deprecated in
must not be included within MathML markup in HTML Content Documents.
HTML Content Document fragments may be included within MathML markup in HTML Content Documents, and, when present, must occur within an annotation-xml child element of an semantics element.

When an HTML Content Document fragment is included as per the above paragraph, the given annotation-xml element's encoding attribute must be set to the media type of the parent HTML Content Document (either application/xhtml+xml or text/html) and its name attribute must be set to alternate-representation.
Any included HTML Content Document fragments must not themselves contain MathML markup.

Any included HTML Content Document fragments must conform to the content model in which the ancestor math element occurs, such that if the math element is replaced by the given HTML Content Document fragment the document remains valid.
Alternative content should be included, and, when present, must be represented as defined in .

section.xreflabel: Embedded MathML â Reading System Conformance
section.title: Reading System Conformance
section.para: A conformant must meet all of the following criteria for processing MathML embedded in HTML Content Documents:

listitem.para: It must support processing of Presentation MathML, and may support processing of Content MathML, using semantics defined by the MathML 3.0 specification .
If it has a , it must support visual rendering of Presentation MathML.

When producing alternative textual content for MathML markup, it should be able to dynamically generate such content from the given Presentation MathML, and if not, must give preference to HTML Content Document fragments followed by the alttext attribute on the math element.

It must regard the mathml property of the
item element as the authoritative definition of whether an HTML Content Document includes embedded MathML.

section.title: Alternative Content
section.para: Reading Systems should be able to generate any necessary alternative textual rendering dynamically using the given Presentation MathML markup (e.g., as output to engines). To support Reading Systems that are not so capable, alternative textual content should be included with each occurrence of the math element in HTML Content Documents.

The alttext attribute on the math element should be used for this purpose primarily when shorter alternative text runs are sufficient. When more extensive alternative text is required, HTML Content Document fragments should be used. (Note that Reading Systems query these two alternative text locations using a defined preference order.)

For Reading System forward compatibility purposes, fallback images may be provided using the altimg attribute on the math element. It is recommended that the dimension and alignment attributes (altimg-width, altimg-height and altimg-valign) be used in conjunction with the altimg attribute.

note.para: Publication Resources referenced from alternative content have conform to the constraints for Publication Resources defined in .

section.title: Embedded SVG
section.para: HTML Content Documents support the embedding of SVG 1.1 document fragments by reference (embedding via reference, for example, from an img or object element) and by inclusion (embedding via direct inclusion of the svg element in the HTML Content Document) .

The content conformance constraints for SVG embedded in HTML Content Documents are the same as defined for SVG Content Documents in , with the exception that SVG embedded in the HTML syntax does not have to meet the XML conformance requirements.
Reading Systems must process SVG embedded in HTML Content Documents as defined in .

note.para: The svg property of the item element indicates that an HTML Content Document contains embedded SVG.

section.title: Embedded SVG and CSS
section.para: For the purposes of styling SVG embedded in HTML Content Documents by reference, Reading Systems must not apply CSS style rules of the containing document to the referenced SVG document.
For the purposes of styling SVG embedded in HTML Content Documents by inclusion, Reading Systems must apply applicable CSS rules of the containing document to the included SVG elements.

note.para: SVG included by reference is processed as a separate document, and may include its own CSS style rules just like an would. Note that this is consistent with situations where an object element references an external element.

section.title: Unicode Restrictions
section.para: This section lists restrictions on the Unicode character repertoire.

varlistentry.term: Private Use Characters and Embedded Fonts

listitem.para: Any included characters that map to a code point within one of the Private Use Area (PUA) ranges as defined in must occur within a string that is styled or attributed in a manner that includes a reference to an embedded font that contains an appropriate glyph for that code point.

The rp element is intended to provide a fallback â an optional parenthesis display around ruby markup â for older version Reading Systems that do not recognize ruby markup. As EPUB 3.1 Reading Systems are ruby-aware, and can provide fallbacks, the use of rp elements in HTML Content Documents is discouraged.

Since the embed element does not provide intrinsic facilities to provide fallbacks for Reading Systems that do not support scripting, its use is discouraged when the resource referenced has scripting components. Authors should use the object element instead.

section.title: The body element
section.para: It is assumed, in formatting, that the default rendering for the body element is consistent with the page-break-before property having been set to always, but this default may be overridden by an appropriate style sheet declaration.

section.title: Foreign Resource Restrictions
section.para: Foreign Resources may be referenced from elements that have explicit intrinsic fallback mechanisms (e.g., many embedded content elements). A Core Media Type resource must be provided via the given element's intrinsic fallback mechanism in such cases.

For both the audio and video elements, flow content embedded within the elements does not represent a Core Media Type fallback, but may be included for rendering in older Reading Systems that do not recognize these elements (e.g., EPUB 2 Reading Systems).
The track element is exempt from the Core Media Type usage rule: Foreign Resources may be referenced from track without the provision of a Core Media Type fallback.

note.para: Refer to manifest fallbacks for the provision of fallbacks for elements without intrinsic mechanisms, such as the iframe and img elements.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: The Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) 1.1 (Second Edition) specification defines a format for representing final-form vector graphics and text.

Although an EPUB Publication typically uses HTML Content Documents as the top-level document type, the use of SVG Content Documents is also permitted. SVGs are typically only used in certain special circumstances, such as when final-form page images are the only suitable representation of the content (as may be the case, for example, in the context of manga or comic books).
This section defines a profile for documents. An instance of an XML document that conforms to this profile is a and is referred to in this specification as an .

note.para: This section defines conformance requirements for SVG Content Documents. Refer to for conformance requirements for SVG embedded in HTML Content Documents.

section.xreflabel: SVG Content Documents â Content Conformance
section.title: Content Conformance

variablelist.para: An must meet all of the following criteria:

listitem.para: It may include references to Foreign Resources provided a fallback to a is included.
It must be an SVG 1.1 document fragment valid to the constructs defined in that specification, and conform to all content conformance constraints expressed in .
It should adhere to the accessibility guidelines given in .
The SVG Content Document filename should use the file extension .svg.

section.title: Restrictions on SVG 1.1
section.para: This specification restricts the content model of SVG Content Documents and SVG embedded in HTML Content Documents as follows:

listitem.para: The Animation Elements and Animation event attributes must not occur.

The foreignObject element must contain either flow content or exactly one body element. This content must represent a valid document fragment of the HTML Content Document model defined in . The foreignObject element's requiredExtensions attribute, if given, must be set to http://www.idpf.org/2007/ops.
The title element must contain only valid HTML Content Document Phrasing content.

section.xreflabel: SVG Content Documents â Reading System Conformance
section.title: Reading System Conformance
section.para: A conformant must meet all of the following criteria for processing SVG Content Documents and SVG embedded in HTML Content Documents:

listitem.para: It must support the language features of SVG that correspond to the feature string http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG11/feature#SVG-dynamic minus the http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG11/feature#Animation and http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG11/feature#AnimationEventsAttribute features (see Feature strings) .
It must meet the Reading System conformance criteria defined in .

If it has an , it must support the visual rendering of SVG using CSS as defined in Section 6 of , and it should support all properties defined in Appendix N of that specification. In the case of embedded SVG, it must also conform to the constraints defined in .
It should support User selection and searching of text within SVG elements.

It must recognize the value http://www.idpf.org/2007/ops of the requiredExtensions attribute when appearing on the switch and foreignObject elements as representing the occurrence of HTML Content Document fragments.

It must regard the svg property of the
item element as the authoritative definition of whether an EPUB HTML Content Document includes embedded SVG.

section.title: Semantic Inflection
section.para: The implementation of the ARIA role attribute is recommended for semantically inflecting SVG elements using the .
The role attribute supersedes the epub:type attribute used in previous versions of this specification for semantic inflection of SVG.

chapter.title: Scripting
chapter.para: EPUB Content Documents may contain scripting using the facilities defined for this in the respective underlying specifications ( and ). When an EPUB Content Document contains scripting, it is referred to in this specification as a . This label also applies to HTML Content Documents when they contain instances of HTML5 forms.

section.title: Scripting Contexts
section.para: This specification defines two contexts in which scripts may appear:

listitem.para: An instance of the script element included in a .
An instance of the script element included in an that is embedded in a parent Content Document using one of the object, iframe or embed elements.

section.para: In both of the above-defined contexts, whether the JavaScript code is embedded directly in the script element or referenced via its src attribute makes no difference to the executing context.

Which context a script is used in determines the rights and restrictions that a Reading System may place on it. Refer to Content Conformance and Reading System Conformance for some specific requirements that must be adhered to (not all Reading Systems may provide the same scripting functionality).

section.xreflabel: Scripted Content Documents â Content Conformance
section.title: Content Conformance

listitem.para: A container-constrained script must not contain instructions for modifying the DOM of the parent Content Document or other contents in the EPUB Publication, and must not contain instructions for manipulating the size of its containing rectangle.

EPUB Content Documents that include scripting must utilize the progressive enhancement technique, which for the purposes of this specification has the following definition: when the document is rendered by a Reading System without scripting support or with scripting support disabled, the top-level document content must retain its integrity, remaining consumable by the User without any information loss or other significant deterioration.
EPUB Content Documents that include scripting â using any inclusion model â should employ relevant accessibility techniques to ensure that the content remains consumable by all Users.

EPUB Content Documents that include scripting â using any inclusion model â may provide fallbacks for such content, either by using intrinsic fallback mechanisms (such as those available for the object and canvas elements) or, when an intrinsic fallback is not applicable, by using a manifest-level fallback.

note.para: The scripted property of the item element indicates that an EPUB Content Document is a .

section.xreflabel: Scripted Content Documents â Reading System Conformance
section.title: Reading System Conformance
section.para: support for scripting is optional. A Reading System that supports scripting must meet the following criteria:

listitem.para: It must support scripting and may support scripting.
It may render Scripted Content Documents as an interactive, scripted User Agent according to .

It must not allow a container-constrained script to modify the DOM of the parent Content Document or other contents in the EPUB Publication, and must not allow it to manipulate the size of its containing rectangle. (Note: Even if a script is not container-constrained, the Reading System may impose restrictions on modifications (see also the dom-manipulation feature).)
It may place additional limitations on the capabilities provided to scripts during execution (e.g., limiting networking).

It must implement the JavaScript navigator extension object epubReadingSystem defined in . It also must support the dom-manipulation and layout-change features defined in in container-constrained scripting contexts.

It must regard the scripted property of the
item element as the authoritative definition of whether an EPUB Content Document includes scripting.

section.para: A Reading System that does not support scripting must meet the following criteria:

listitem.para: It must process fallbacks for scripted content as defined in .

note.para: Reading Systems may render Scripted Content Documents in a manner that disables other EPUB capabilities and/or provides a different rendering and User experience (e.g., by disabling pagination).
Authors choosing to restrict the usage of scripting to the model will ensure a more consistent User experience between scripted and non-scripted content (e.g., consistent pagination behavior).

Authors should use declarative techniques whenever practical to increase the interoperability, longevity and accessibility of their EPUB Publications, and avoid the inclusion of scripting whenever practical.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.para: All EPUB Authors and Reading System developers need to be aware of the security issues that arise when scripted content is executed by a Reading System. As the underlying scripting model employed by Reading Systems and browsers is the same, the same kinds of issues encountered in Web contexts must be taken into consideration.

Each Reading System should establish if the scripts in a particular document are to be trusted or not. It is recommended that all scripts be treated as untrusted (and potentially malicious), and that all vectors of attack be examined and protected against. In particular, the following should be considered:

listitem.para: an attack against the runtime environment (e.g., stealing files from a 's hard drive);
an attack against the Reading System itself (e.g., stealing a list of a User's books or causing unexpected behavior);
an attack of one Content Document against another (e.g., stealing data that originated in a different document);
an attack of an unencrypted script against an encrypted portion of a document (e.g., an injected malicious script extracting protected content);
an attack against the local network (e.g., stealing data from a server behind a firewall).

section.para: The following recommendations are provided as a guide to handling untrusted scripts:

listitem.para: Reading Systems should behave as if a unique domain were allocated to each Content Document, as browser-based security relies heavily on document URLs and domains. Adopting this approach will isolate documents from each other and from other Internet domains, thereby limiting access to external URLs, cookies, DOM storage, etc.
Reading Systems that enable scripting and network access should also consider including methods to notify the user that network activity is occurring and/or that allow them to disable it.

note.para: In practice, Reading Systems may share domains across documents, but they still should maintain isolation between documents.

If parts of a document are encrypted and parts are not, or if different encryption keys are used for different parts of the document, a unique per-document domain might not provide sufficient protection.

listitem.para: If a Reading System allows persistent data to be stored, that data should be treated as sensitive. Scripts may save persistent data through cookies and DOM storage, but Reading Systems may block such attempts. Reading Systems that do allow data to be stored must ensure that it is not made available to other unrelated documents (e.g., ones that could have been spoofed). In particular, checking for a matching document identifier (or similar metadata) is not a valid method to control access to persistent data.
Reading Systems that allow local storage should also provide methods for Users to inspect, disable, or delete that data. The data should be destroyed if the corresponding EPUB Publication is deleted.

section.para: Note that compliance with these recommendations does not guarantee protection from the possible attacks listed above; developers must examine each potential vulnerability within the context of their Reading System.

section.title: Event Model Considerations
section.para: Reading Systems should follow the DOM Event model as per and pass UI events to the scripting environment before performing any default action associated with these events. Reading System implementers should ensure that scripts cannot disable critical functionality (such as navigation) to constrain the extent to which a potentially malicious script could impact their Reading Systems. As a result, although the scripting environment should be able to cancel the default action of any event, some events either might not be passed through or might not be cancelable.

Authors should take into account the wide variety of possible Reading System implementations when adding scripting functionality to their EPUB Publications (e.g., not all devices have physical keyboard, and in many cases a soft keyboard is only activated only for text input elements). Consequently, relying on keyboard events alone is not recommended; alternative ways to trigger the desired action should always be provided.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: This section defines rules for the expression and interpretation of dimensional properties of EPUB Content Documents marked as pre-paginated in the .
This specification does not define how the the initial containing block, will be placed within the Reading System content display area.

note.para: Refer to for information on how to designate that a , or its individual spine items, are to be rendered in a pre-paginated manner (i.e., with fixed width and height dimensions).

section.xreflabel: Fixed Layouts â Reading System Conformance
section.title: Reading System Conformance
section.para: A conformant must meet all of the following criteria for processing Fixed-Layout Documents:

listitem.para: It should allocate the full content rendering area for the document.
It must use the dimensions expressed in the viewport meta tag to render HTML Content Documents, but may obtain these dimensions from the package .
It must use the dimensions expressed in the viewBox attribute to render SVG Content Documents, but may obtain these dimensions from the package .
It must use the dimensions expressed in the content in the case of discrepancies with the package .

section.title: Viewport Rendering
section.para: When rendering Fixed-Layout Documents, the default intent is that the content rendering area should occupy as much of the available application screen area as possible. Reading Systems should not inject additional content such as border, margins, headers or footers into the viewport or the application area surrounding the viewport.

note.para: The exposure of Reading System control widgets to the is implementation-specific and not included in the above behavioral expectations.

section.title: Content Dimensions for HTML and SVG
section.para: Each referenced from a spine item that has the pre-paginated value set must contain the viewport (for HTML) or viewBox (for SVG) dimension expressions as defined below, regardless of whether the value is set via the global rendition:layout property for the or on a spine-level override.
For both HTML and SVG Content Documents, the dimension expressions define the CSS initial containing block (ICB) expressed in CSS Pixels .

section.title: Expressing ICB Dimensions in HTML
section.para: For HTML Content Documents, the ICB dimensions must be expressed in a viewport meta tag using the syntax defined in . In this version of this specification, only the width and height expressions must be recognized by Reading Systems.

section.para: Reading Systems must clip HTML content to the ICB dimensions declared in the viewport meta tag; content positioned outside of the initial containing block will not be visible. When the ICB aspect ratio does not match the aspect ratio of the Reading System content display area, Reading Systems may position the ICB inside the area to accommodate the user interface; in other words, added letter-boxing space may appear on either side (or both) of the content.

section.title: Expressing ICB Dimensions in SVG
section.para: For SVG Content Documents, the ICB dimensions must be expressed using the viewBox attribute .

chapter.title: Cascading Style Sheets
chapter.para: This section defines a profile for Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) intended to be used for styling of HTML Content Documents. An instance of a CSS Style Sheet that conforms to this profile is a .

caution.para: The EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile references CSS specifications that are still works in progress and may change in incompatible ways. When utilizing features from such specifications, authors should consider the inherent risks in terms of the potential impact on interoperability and document longevity.

note.para: The EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile employs the usage of the -epub- prefix for a number of CSS3 property names, as detailed below. As the CSS3 modules that define these properties mature and stabilize, EPUB authoring guidelines may encourage authors to also include unprefixed equivalents of these properties in EPUB 3.1 Style Sheets.

section.xreflabel: Cascading Style Sheets â Content Conformance
section.title: Content Conformance
section.para: A conformant CSS Style Sheet must meet all of the following criteria:

listitem.para: It must adhere to all content restrictions given in .
It may include constructs not explicitly identified in the EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile, but should be authored so that rendering fidelity does not depend on such additional constructs.
It must be UTF-8 or UTF-16 encoded.

note.para: All s referenced from a CSS Style Sheet must conform to the constraints for Publication Resources defined in

section.xreflabel: Cascading Style Sheets â Reading System Conformance
section.title: Reading System Conformance

listitem.para: Reading Systems with a should support â render as defined by the corresponding specification in the Viewport â all CSS constructs included in this profile unless detailed otherwise in .
Reading Systems may support additional CSS constructs not explicitly identified in the EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile, and must handle any unsupported constructs as defined in .

note.para: Reading Systems have varying capabilities with regards to CSS rendering support, so may ignore some or all style information of an CSS Style Sheet.

In addition, even when a Reading System does have a , it is likely to render content in a manner that differs from typical HTML5 User Agents (e.g., paginating content rather than providing a infinitely scrolling surface).

section.title: CSS 2.1
section.para: The style baseline of the EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile is Cascading Style Sheets Level 2 Revision 1 . The profile includes all style sheet constructs normatively defined in , with the following exceptions:

listitem.para: The absolute value of the position property should be used only with HTML Content Documents whose rendition:layout property has been set to pre-paginated.
The fixed value of the position property is not part of the EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile. To avoid potential rendering and interoperability issues, it should not be included in a CSS Style Sheet.
The direction and unicode-bidi properties must not be included in a CSS Style Sheet. Authors should use appropriate markup to express directionality information instead.

section.para: Reading Systems that have a must support the font-family property.

section.title: CSS Fonts Level 3
section.para: The EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile includes @font-face rules and descriptors as defined in the CSS Fonts Module Level 3 specification, using syntax as defined in and semantics as defined in .
Reading Systems with a must support OpenType and WOFF fonts embedded using the @font-face rule.

Fonts embedded in Content Documents or CSS Style Sheets using the @font-face mechanism may be Foreign Resources. Reading Systems must use the rules for matching font styles when identifying a fallback for an unsupported font type.
In addition, Reading Systems must support at least the following @font-face font descriptors.
For forwards compatibility with EPUB 2 Reading Systems that do not support @font-face rules, authors should reference a generic font using the font-family property.

note.para: Refer to for Reading System font obfuscation requirements.

section.title: CSS Text Level 3
section.para: The EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile includes -epub- prefixed versions of the following properties from the CSS Text Level 3 specification using syntax as defined in and semantics as defined in .

listitem.para: -epub-hyphens*

section.para: * The -epub-hyphens property does not include support for the value all.

In addition, the EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile includes the unprefixed text-transform property from CSS Text Level 3 using semantics as defined in and syntax as defined in , with the exception that the fullwidth and fullsize-kana values are prefixed in the EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile (-epub-fullwidth and -epub-fullsize-kana, respectively).
Note that the CSS Text Level 3 module has dropped support for the fullsize-kana value since the EPUB 3.0 revision. The EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile retains this value, but now defines its semantics as below:

listitem.para: This value represents a mapping of HIRAGANA or KATAKANA characters as shown in . This value is typically used for Japanese ruby annotation text.

section.title: CSS Text Decoration Level 3
section.para: The EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile includes -epub- prefixed versions of the following properties from the CSS Text Decoration Level 3 specification using syntax as defined in and semantics as defined in .

section.title: CSS Writing Modes
section.para: With exceptions for the direction and unicode-bidi properties as noted below, the EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile includes all of the features defined in the CSS Writing Modes Module Level 3 specification using -epub- prefixed property names, syntax as defined in and semantics as defined in . Furthermore, as specified in , both "sideways" and "mixed" are permitted as values of the -epub-text-orientation property. The values "vertical-right", "rotate-right", "rotate-left", "rotate-normal" and "auto" of this property are deprecated.

note.para: The semantics of "vertical-right", "rotate-right", "rotate-left", "rotate-normal", and "auto" is the same as that of "mixed", "sideways-right", "sideways-left", "sideways" and "use-glyph-orientation" in , respectively.

section.para: The -epub-text-combine property is deprecated, and the -epub-text-combine-horizontal property from added.

note.para: The -epub-text-combine property's values can be mapped to -epub-text-combine-horizontal as follows: 'none' to 'none' and 'horizontal' to 'all'. The syntax 'horizontal <number>' is treated as an error.

section.para: The direction and unicode-bidi properties from are not included in the EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile. Authors should use appropriate markup to express directionality information instead.

section.title: Selectors
section.para: The EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile includes support for the Selectors Level 3 specification.

section.title: Media Queries
section.para: The EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile includes @media and @import rules with media queries as defined in the Media Queries specification.

section.title: CSS Namespaces
section.para: The EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile includes the @namespace rule defined in for declaring the default namespace for a style sheet and for binding prefixes to namespaces.

section.title: CSS Multi-Column Layout
section.para: The EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile includes all of the features defined in the CSS Multi-column Layout Module specification with the exception of the column-span property.

caution.para: Authors should not rely on column behavior in overflow conditions as this behavior is unstable and may change.
Pagination algorithms are not fully defined in CSS. Authors should therefore expect exact pagination points to vary from Reading System to Reading System.

section.para: Reading Systems must treat the oeb-column-number property as an alias for the column-count property. The use of the oeb-column-number property in CSS Style Sheets is deprecated; this conformance requirement may be removed in the next major version of EPUB.

section.title: Ruby Positioning
section.para: The EPUB 3.1 CSS Profile includes the -epub-ruby-position property as defined below:
This property controls the placement of ruby text with respect to its base text. Values have the following meanings:

listitem.para: Ruby text is positioned on the over side of the ruby base.
Ruby text is positioned on the under side of the ruby base.
Ruby text is positioned on the right side of the base text. (This value is typically used for Zhuyin Fuhao (Bopomofo) ruby.)

note.para: The -epub-ruby-position property will become an alias for the ruby-position property in the CSS Ruby Module .

section.title: Display Property Values oeb-page-head and oeb-page-foot [DEPRECATED]
section.para: The oeb-page-head and oeb-page-foot values are deprecated and expected to be removed or replaced in a future version of EPUB.
Authors may continue to include these values in CSS Style Sheets to define running headers and footers. Refer to the oeb-page-head oeb-page-foot definitions in for more information.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: The W3C Pronunciation Lexicon Specification defines syntax and semantics for XML-based pronunciation lexicons to be used by Automatic Speech Recognition and engines.
The following sections define conformance criteria for PLS documents when included in EPUB Publications, and rules for associating PLS Documents with HTML Content Documents.

section.title: EPUB Publication Conformance
section.para: A conformant of an must meet all of the following criteria for inclusion of PLS Documents:

listitem.para: PLS Documents may be associated with HTML Content Documents. Each HTML Content Document may contain zero or more PLS Document associations.

PLS Documents must be associated with the to which it applies using the link element with its rel attribute set to pronunciation and its type attribute set to the PLS media type (application/pls+xml).
The link element hreflang attribute should be specified on each PLS link, and its value must match the language for which the pronunciation lexicon is relevant when specified.
PLS Documents must meet the content conformance criteria defined in .
PLS Documents must be represented and located as defined in .

informalexample.para: The following example shows two PLS Documents (one for Chinese and one for Mongolian) associated with an HTML Content Document.

section.title: Content Conformance
section.para: To be considered a , a PLS Document must meet all of the following criteria:

listitem.para: It must be valid to the RELAX NG schema for PLS documents available at the URI http://www.w3.org/TR/pronunciation-lexicon/pls.rng .
The PLS Document filename should use the file extension .pls.

section.xreflabel: PLS Documents â Reading System Conformance
section.title: Reading System Conformance
section.para: A conformant must meet all of the following criteria for processing PLS Documents:

listitem.para: Reading Systems with capabilities should support PLS.
Reading Systems that support PLS must process PLS documents as defined in .

Reading Systems that support PLS must apply the supplied pronunciation instructions to all text nodes in the current HTML Content Document whose language matches the language for which the pronunciation lexicon is relevant . The algorithm for matching language tags is defined in BCP47.

When a pronunciation rule is specified more than once for a given string target in a given language, the last occurrence of the rule takes precedence, in such a way that any previously-defined pronunciation rule gets overridden.

Reading Systems that support PLS and the SSML Attributes must let any pronunciation instructions provided via the ssml:ph attribute take precedence in cases where a pls:grapheme matches a text node of an element that carries the ssml:ph attribute.

section.title: Syntax
section.para: ReadingSystem = navigator.epubReadingSystem;

section.title: Description
section.para: The epubReadingSystem object provides an interface through which a can query information about a 's Reading System.
The object exposes a number of properties, about the Reading System, such as its name and version, and provides the hasFeature method which can be invoked to determine the features it supports.

informalexample.para: Example JavaScript function that displays the name of the current Reading System.

section.title: Properties
section.para: The following properties must be made available for retrieving information about the Reading System.

tr.td: Returns a String value representing the name of the Reading System (e.g., "iBooks", "Kindle").
Returns a String value representing the version of the Reading System (e.g., "1.0", "2.1.1").

td.para: Returns a String value representing the style of layout for the content.
A Reading System will typically return one of the values "paginated" or "scrolling", but may define values for any additional layout formats it supports.

section.title: Syntax
section.para: hasFeature(feature[, version])

section.title: Description
section.para: For recognized features, the hasFeature method returns a boolean value indicating whether any version is supported.
If the optional version parameter is included, the return value indicates support only for the specified version.
The method returns undefined if the feature is not recognized by the Reading System.

informalexample.para: Example JavaScript function that displays whether the current Reading System supports scripted manipulation of the DOM.

section.title: Features
section.para: The following table details the features that must be recognized by all Reading Systems that support scripting (spine-level or container-constrained). Reading Systems may support some or all of these features (refer to for more information).
Feature names are case-insensitive.

tr.td: Scripts may make structural changes to the documentâs DOM (applies to spine-level scripting only).
Scripts may modify attributes and CSS styles that affect content layout (applies to spine-level scripting only).
The device supports touch events and the Reading System passes touch events to the content.
The device supports mouse events and the Reading System passes mouse events to the content.
The device supports keyboard events and the Reading System passes keyboard events to the content.

section.para: If a Reading System supports a feature defined in this section, it must return a true value both when queried without the version parameter set and when that parameter is set to the value "1.0". Otherwise, it must return false. Reading System developers should not change the version number of these features independently of this specification.

Additional features may be added by Reading System developers, but future versions of this specification may append to this list in ways that may conflict or be incompatible with any such custom additions.
